titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frances Hesselbein Papers, 1942-2013 AIS.2013.16
titlestmt.author: Kathleen Donahoe.

physdesc.extent: (38 Record Center boxes, 5.5 Hollinger boxes, 1 flat box, 1 tube, and 3 media boxes)

did.abstract: Frances Hesselbein (1915-2022) was a figure in the world of leadership and nonprofit management, having served as the National Executive Director of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for nearly fifteen years. She was the Chair of The Frances Hesselbein Leadership Forum at the University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Public and International Affairs (GSPIA), Johnson Institute for Responsible Leadership, and served as the President and CEO for the organization's previous iterations. The collection consists of business materials from her organization, such as meeting minutes and conference planning information, as well as the different publications produced by the Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management, the Leader to Leader Institute, and the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute. The personal materials in the collection include event information, correspondence, as well as materials dealing with the Girl Scouts of the United States of America. There are paper records, as well as video cassettes, audio tapes, photographic images, and CD-ROMs included in the collection.
did.langmaterial: The majority of the collection is in English; some items are in a number of different languages, such as books published in Portuguese, Korean, Japanese, and Chinese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Frances Hesselbein Papers document the life and work of one of the leaders in the world of nonprofit management. The collection contains a wide variety of materials, including information on the Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management (1990-2002), the Leader to Leader Institute (2003-2011), and the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute (2012-2017), as well as Hesselbein's personal life. The records are divided into two subgroups, the records of the Hesselbein Institute and its predecessors; and the personal records of Frances Hesselbein. Materials are dated as early as the 1930s and 1940s, up until the present day. Most of the material comes from the time towards the end of Hesselbein's tenure with the Girl Scouts of the United States of America in the 1980s and continues through her work with The Drucker Foundation/Leader to Leader/Hesselbein Institute.

The records in these subgroups represent two distinct categories of information, as specified by the donor. In the first subgroup, that of the institution, there are materials relating to Hesselbein, but there are also materials more specifically concerned with the Institute itself, such as meeting minutes, conference plans, publications, staff correspondence, and audio/visual materials produced by or relating to the institution. There are also records of Peter Drucker himself, such as articles written over his lifetime and information related to the Drucker Institute at Claremont Graduate University in Claremont, California, where Drucker was a professor.

In the second subgroup, containing personal material, there are records related to Hesselbein's time with the Girl Scouts, information on other nonprofit organizations with which she spent time, copies of speeches given in the past 35 years, and audio/visual materials relating to these topics, as well as Hesselbein herself. There is also information on events attended by Hesselbein, and documents relating to her family life as well. The materials in this subgroup, unlike in the first, almost always deal specifically with Frances Hesselbein.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Frances Richards Hesselbein (1915-2022) was born in Johnstown, Pennsylvania, in 1915, the oldest of three children. Her education includes classes at the University of Pittsburgh's Johnstown Campus, though after her father died she left school and supported her family. She married John D. Hesselbein, an alumnus of the University of Pittsburgh, who worked for the Johnstown Tribune-Democrat and later opened his own documentary-filmmaking and photography studio. While assisting her husband at the studio and raising their son, John, Hesselbein was approached by a local group of women with the request to take over the leadership of a local Girl Scout troop. Despite not having a girl in the troop herself, Hesselbein agreed and took charge since the troop would be disbanded without a leader. She stayed with that group of girls until they graduated high school. Later, she was asked to take on the role of Talus Rock Council Executive Director in Johnstown, which she accepted. Following a successful period in this position, she was invited to apply for the position of National Executive Director (CEO) of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America. She served in that role from 1976-1990 as the first woman to be appointed to that position from within the organization.

During her time with the Girl Scouts, Hesselbein helped to transform the organization. She had the uniform redesigned as well as the logo, worked to increase minority representation, and also helped create the Daisy program for 6-year-old girls. Membership in the Girl Scouts increased greatly under Hesselbein's leadership as well, reaching up to 2.25 million girls in all. Hesselbein also implemented her leadership strategy of "Banning the Hierarchy", incorporating the idea of "Circular Management." This strategy, among others, would follow Hesselbein when she retired from the Girl Scouts.

After leaving the Girl Scouts in 1990, Hesselbein was invited to work on a new project. Her friend Peter Drucker, often called "The Father of Modern Management" for his business expertise, was to be honored by a new nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting leadership and management skills and tools, which would eventually be called the Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management. Hesselbein led the organization through the 1990s in different roles. In 2003, the organization was renamed the Leader to Leader Institute though the mission of the institute remained the same. In 2012, it would become the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute, which Hesselbein led as President and CEO. In 2017, Hesselbein partnered with the University of Pittsburgh, who acquired the organization, which was renamed The Frances Hesselbein Leadership Forum. The Hesselbein Forum resides in the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs (GSPIA), Johnson Institute for Responsible Leadership.
Hesselbein served as the Chair of the Hesselbein Forum, as well as the editor-in-chief of the Leader to Leader Journal.

Hesselbein was very active in various nonprofit organizations in addition to her work at the Hesselbein Forum. She worked with retired members of the military to promote the Generals in Transition and the Investment in America programs. She has served on the boards of nonprofits and corporations, including the Bright China Social Fund and Mutual of America Life Insurance Company. In 2009, working with her alma mater, Hesselbein helped establish the Frances Hesselbein Global Academy for Student Leadership and Civic Engagement at the University of Pittsburgh, inviting students around the world to participate in sessions focused on creating the leaders of tomorrow.

Frances Hesselbein received a number of awards, including 22 honorary degrees. In 1998 she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Bill Clinton, as "a pioneer for women, diversity, and opportunity." She also served as the West Point Class of 1951 Chair for the Study of Leadership, a two-year appointment. Hesselbein was the first woman and the first non-graduate to hold this position. Hesselbein was also named a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania.
Frances Hesselbein died on December 11, 2022 at her home in Easton, Pennsylvania at the age of 107 years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Frances Hesselbein Institute Papers are a subgroup of the overall collection. Records in this subgroup come from the Drucker Foundation (1990-2002), which was later renamed the Leader to Leader Institute (2003-2011), and then again later renamed the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute (2012-2017); all this occurred while the organization maintained its focus on leadership, management, and the nonprofit sector. Included in this subgroup are administrative materials from these organizations, as well as records of Peter Drucker himself. There are press articles on the institutions and any associated entities, as well as publications both from the organizations and about them. Any media for the Hesselbein Institute and its related organizations is featured in Series VIII of this subgroup. The materials in this subgroup are mainly dated from the late 1980s to the early 2000s, though there are some exceptions from both earlier and later times.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the board meeting materials, management reports, correspondence between board members, notes from Frances Hesselbein, information on the Foundation's name change to the Leader to Leader Institute (including legal documents), financial information, and records relating to the Drucker Foundation's Annual Conference and Innovation Award. The materials are dated from 1990-2003, when the Foundation underwent a name change. Researchers should refer to Series VIII of this subgroup for The Drucker Foundation's A/V materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains board meeting materials, management reports, event plans, correspondence, legal and financial documents, annual reports, potential partnership information of the Leader to Leader Institute. The materials are dated from 2003-2011, after which the name of the organization was changed again to the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute, though its focus remained the same. Researchers should refer to Series VIII of this subgroup for A/V material relating to the Leader to Leader Institute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains fundraising information for the Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute, as well as legal documents for the organization's name change from the Leader to Leader Institute. There is also correspondence, event plans and invitations, and some financial information. The documents in this series are dated from 2012-2013. Audio/Visual material from this organization is available in Series VIII of this subgroup.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes a variety of different publications, including books, workbooks, journals, and some magazines, dated from 1985-2014. The books include those published by the Drucker Foundation and Leader to Leader Institute and are featured in a variety of languages. They are organized chronologically by publication date, though if numerous versions of the same copy existed, these copies were placed together. The series also contains information from various management seminars. Some are products of the Drucker Foundation, while others are from outside nonprofit organizations with which the Drucker Foundation worked. The outside publications provide a sample of the various organizations with which the Drucker Foundation and its later iterations interacted. Many of the documents deal with the Drucker Foundation's Self-Assessment Tool. This series also contains information on the publication of some of these items, specifically those dealing with the Drucker Foundation and later the Leader to Leader Institute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains all press and news articles on Peter Drucker, The Drucker Foundation, The Leader to Leader Institute, and projects and programs planned by the organizations. The material is dated from 1979-2009, with the bulk of the material focusing on the 1990s and the early 2000s. The Peter Drucker subseries includes obituaries and tributes published after Drucker's death, which accounts for the posthumous dating.

Leader to Leader book interview materials
Leader to Leader Institute press articles
Leader to Leader Institute press folder materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information on Peter F. Drucker. There are also articles written by/about Drucker, interviews, correspondence, information on a Drucker documentary, information on Drucker's Presidential Medal of Freedom, speech information and transcripts, and information on the Peter Drucker Archives at Claremont Graduate School in California. The material is dated from 1942-2011, though the bulk of the material is from the 1980s to the early 2000s. Press materials on Peter Drucker may be found in Series V of this subgroup.

did.unittitle: Drucker Graduate School of Management information
The Drucker Project: A Transnational Opportunity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Frances Hesselbein Community Innovation Fellows program was a project with the Drucker Foundation to promote the leaders of nonprofit organizations and give them the opportunities to improve both their organizations and the world around them. Fellows applied with a specific goal in mind for their organization and the ways in which they thought to accomplish these tasks, and after being selected were given a mentor from the management community. Those chosen were also provided various opportunities to meet and discuss topics with other leaders during their year-long appointment. This series contains information on applicants from the years 1997-2002, as well as various pieces of writing from different Fellows, schedules of events, and selection committee materials. We do ask researchers to sign a letter of confidentiality when accessing these files.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researcher access to Subgroup A., Series VII. Hesselbein Fellows is subject to the Archives & Special Collections confidentiality agreement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the audio and video recordings for the Frances Hesselbein Institute subgroup. Materials in this series include video cassette tapes, audio cassette tapes, CD-ROMs, DVDs, and various forms of photographic images. Most of the videos were produced by the Drucker Foundation and Leader to Leader Institute, and a large number of the video and audio cassette tapes feature recordings from the conferences held by these institutions throughout the years. There are also videos of Peter Drucker speeches, and seminars run by Frances Hesselbein. The Drucker Foundation subseries contains four unidentified boxes of open reel audio tape. The A/V materials have been arranged within each subseries starting with the oldest formats, such as Betacam or VHS tapes, and ending with the last, usually DVDs. Multiple formats of some productions were kept to ensure preservation of the content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Frances Hesselbein Personal Papers are a subgroup of the overall Frances Hesselbein collection. The records contained in this group are of both a personal and professional nature, though they relate to Hesselbein's life outside of The Drucker Foundation and its later versions. This subgroup therefore includes information pertaining to Hesselbein's relationship with the Girl Scouts of the United States of America, both during her time in that organization and after. There is information on publications from Hesselbein herself, such as specific materials related to the creation of her autobiography. Press and event materials contained in the subgroup relate to both Hesselbein and her colleagues or organizations with which she was associated. Hesselbein's speeches dating back to the mid-1970s are also included here. The media for this subgroup includes materials from the Girl Scouts, but focuses mainly on Hesselbein herself, with some material from her family as well. The media materials are mainly dated from the 1980s to the present day, though there are some items that originate from the earlier times.

did.unittitle: Girl Scouts of the United States of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents from Frances Hesselbein's time as CEO of the Girl Scouts, as well as later years. It includes correspondence, management publications, board meeting materials, event plans and information, management reports, and items such as the organizational newsletter announcing Hesselbein as the new CEO. There are a variety of materials dealing with the 100th anniversary celebration that occurred in 2012, including conference information, correspondence, and a book from the Girl Scouts on the topic. The documents range from 1968-2012, and media for the Girl Scouts may be found in Series IX of this subgroup.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes different forms of publications, including books, workbooks, journals, and some magazines, dated from 1960-2013. The books include those written by Frances Hesselbein, or those featuring her in some form. They are organized chronologically by publication date. Many of the records in this series deal with Hesselbein's process for writing, including materials sent to colleagues for editing, and correspondence on the matters of Hesselbein's books. These materials also include the drafts of excerpts from Hesselbein's books. There are also publications from organizations with which Hesselbein was affiliated or in whose activities she was interested, such as a newsletter from the Daughters of the American Revolution. The inclusion of these items provides a view of other organizations Hesselbein considers important or worthwhile.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this series is both professional and personal, and does not include the correspondence between board members of the organization Frances Hesselbein has helped to lead. It includes thank you notes, handwritten letters between friends, correspondence dealing with proposed projects, and letters from Frances Hesselbein of a professional nature. The letters are in alphabetized folders, which are then organized chronologically. Some files contain information on things mentioned in the letters, which were included here in order to preserve context. The correspondence dates range from 1989-2014, though for some materials no date was discernable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains all press and news articles on Frances Hesselbein, nonprofit organizations in which Frances Hesselbein was involved, friends of Frances Hesselbein, and topics in management. It includes materials on the Girl Scouts of the United States, with material on Hesselbein and the organization itself. The press materials include brochures, interviews, and magazine and newspaper articles. For the friends and colleagues of Hesselbein, pieces of the subject's writing were also kept where available. The materials in this series date from 1955 to 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the information for the many events attended by Frances Hesselbein. It includes invitations, conference materials, event plans, itineraries, correspondence pertaining to the event, and in some instances photographs from the event are also included here. The records are arranged in chronological order, from 1986-2012. In most cases, video footage or photographs of events are available in Series IX.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the information Frances Hesselbein collected on various nonprofit organizations, including those of which she was an advisor/board member. There are annual reports of the organizations included here, as well as publications specific to the nonprofits, and information of other advisors/board members/personnel. The materials are arranged in alphabetical order by the name of the organization. Materials for this series date from 1985 to 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains speeches made by Frances Hesselbein, speeches made about her, and her collection of speech reference files. The speeches are generally transcripts of presentations, though there are some reading copies. They are arranged chronologically, with the undated materials present at the end of each subseries. Speeches that were originally grouped with extraneous materials, such as an invitation to the event at which the speech was given, were separated out of the rest and given individual files. These speeches appear after the rest of the chronologically ordered materials. The speech reference files were kept in their original order and retain the names given to them by Hesselbein and her associates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials of a personal nature, such as pieces of writing from Frances Hesselbein's family members and birthday messages. It also includes a variety of certificates and awards given to Hesselbein over the course of her life. Media of a personal nature may be found in Series IX, which includes family photographs as well as videotapes of some of her public appearances. This series contains speech transcripts from Frances Hesselbein, speeches made about Frances Hesselbein, and reference material used to write speeches by Ms. Hesselbein. The speeches range in date from 1981 2013, though there are gaps in the time frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the audio and video recordings in the Frances Hesselbein Personal Papers subgroup. Materials in this series include video cassettes, audio cassettes, CD-ROMs, DVDs, and photographic images. There are videos of Frances Hesselbein during her time with the Girl Scouts, as well as videos produced by that organization. The videos also include her personal appearances, such as the video broadcast of Hesselbein being awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. The audio cassettes include dictated notes from Hesselbein, as well as some interviews. There are a select number of photographs, including some family photos dating throughout the 20th century.
